Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2011 08:58PM jenn_h wrote: lamom, I don't want to be scary either, but I found a lump that did not show on ultrasound or mammogram, it took the cancer moving into the lymph nodes under my arms for them to finaslly biopsy. I guess in retrospect I wish I would have asked for a biopsy in the beginning, but I was scared it would hurt (it didn't at all by the way). This is certainly not typical, but just remember you know your body better than anyone else and if only for peace of mind you should at least get a second opinion.
Posts.Title: Negative Ultrasound, but still feel Lump lamom318 Deborah12345678

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2013 05:40AM jenn_h wrote: hi, I believe we were in the feb chemo gals group together back "in the beginning ". I finished chemo, had dbl mastectomy and lymph node removal and went on to radiation which I finished oct 2011. A routine Pap smear and ultrasound in November showed enlarged ovaries and this became my first mets. By summer 2012 my lungs and liver and bones were invaded. I have been on xeloda and avastin since, but today got news that 4 biopsies taken from lumps near my skin All over the place were positive. Have to wait to see docs tues and wed so I have no idea where I'll be heading next treatment wise.
Posts.Title: How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: jenn_h wrote: I've been on xeloda now for about 8 months and have hand/foot syndrome. I'm wondering if anyone has any great sneaker/ shoe recommendations? “Anyone can give up, it's the easiest thing in the world to do. But to hold it together when everyone else would understand if you fell apart, that's true strength.” Dx 2/4/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage IV, 14/22 nodes, mets, ER+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Xeloda and hand foot syndrome jenn_h JoyE1947

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2013 01:57AM jenn_h wrote: I have been On Xeloda for a little over a year. I started on 4000 mg a day. When my hands and feet got to a point where my dr graded them worse she changed my scrip to 3000 day and I am two weeks on 1 off. My worst issues are opening things like jars or water bottles (I find pampered chef bottle opener to work great), writing can be difficult. My feet hurt to the point that I cannot go barefoot anymore. I like to wear crocs around the house as they are nice and spongy. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Recovery Time for Hand and Foot Side Effect CalicoCat DancingVeggie

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2011 11:47PM jenn_h wrote: Laura, please check with your onc about hese cold caps, I have heard some things that were not very good about them. Losing my hair was my biggest worry...seems so silly I know, we have cancer but we are mortified over losing our hair. However let me say that the whole anticipation of it was so much worse than it actually happenening! I have to say now that it is slowly growing back that it really wasn't bad at all...just think, never a bad hair day! It is so nice not to shave too! I had lots of cute hats and some nice scarves (I never wore a wig bc it just wasn't comfortable). If you do lose your hair I highly recommend a Survivor Buff (from the tv show, but they make them not for the show too), very comfortable! You will be amazed how fast the time goes!
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed and trying to keep it together Leighsa Joan811

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 09:19PM jenn_h wrote: Leighsa, sorry to have to meet you this way, but so glad you found this place. When I speak to anybody about BC or give any advice the first thing I recommend is this site, it has been a lifesaver for me!! I had chemo beginning last Feb, double mastectomy and ax. lymph nodes from one side in June and then the lymph nodes on other side last week. I have to do physical therapy for shoulder movement now and start radiation and then move on to tamoxifin...it's a long road, but it has gone kind of fast for me as I bet it will for you too.Â  Hugs and prayers go out to you during your journey!
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed and trying to keep it together Leighsa Joan811

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 10:18AM jenn_h wrote: Hi all, I guess today I received my final diagnosis...well maybe, still so much to learn I guess. Biopsy of breast says stage 3 inflammatory bc. I have copies of all my paper work from my surgeon but I don't see this ER/PR or HER thing on there and don't even know what they mean. I guess my next step is getting the oncologist on board and starting chemo. The doctor has concerns bc the spot in the breast is so small. I am worried about the cancer being somewhere else. There is a wealth of info on here but so much to soak up and I'm so tired! Want to move on and kick this thing! Those of you who have had the chemo, did you all lose your hair (I know, such a silly thing to worry about...but it's there)
Posts.Title: Finally a diagnosis geocachelinda AnneW
